awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Preparing to Teach Mathematics with Technology - Examining Student Practice [PTMT-ESP]
awd_abstract_narration:
Preparing to Teach Mathematics with Technology - Examining Student Practice (PTMT - ESP) is an IUSE Development and Implementation project. It will address the documented need for undergraduate prospective secondary mathematics teachers (PSMTs) to possess strong technological pedagogical content knowledge needed to incorporate technology-based mathematics tasks in their future classrooms. Engaging students in meaningful mathematical tasks and capitalizing on available technological tools has been shown to improve attitudes towards mathematics and increase learning. Whether or not the use of technology will enhance students' learning depends on teachers' decisions when using technology tools to design and implement meaningful tasks. These decisions are informed by teachers' knowledge and application of mathematics, technology, and pedagogy. PTMT - ESP will develop and research a set of video case materials to support PSMTs' development of this knowledge. Furthermore, this project will grow and support a community of technology-using mathematics teacher-educators at other universities through professional learning workshops and the distribution of materials on a free web-based portal. Strong preparation of secondary mathematics teachers is needed to support future generations of students prepared to enter STEM fields. Ensuring teachers are prepared to anticipate and draw upon students' understanding in technological contexts by improving their use of technology tools in mathematics classroom will better prepare students to pursue STEM careers, in support of the national interest.  
 
PTMT-ESP is a collaborative project across four institutions that will build on the theoretical foundations of technological pedagogical content knowledge, video case pedagogies, and professional noticing, along with the success of previous PTMT projects (DUE ​0442319, 0817253, 1123001)​. The PTMT-ESP project will utilize design-based research to create, refine and study video-enhanced materials for PSMTs to examine secondary students' authentic mathematical practices on technology-based algebraic tasks. Three objectives provide a framework for the project's activities. First is the design and refinement of seven curriculum modules for undergraduate mathematics education students to examine secondary students' mathematical practices when engaging with technology-based algebra tasks. Second is the execution of a research study to examine PSMTs' development related to understandings of secondary students' technology-based algebraic practices and their own algebraic knowledge. Third is the expansion of support for existing teacher educator communities through professional learning opportunities. The research that corresponds with the creation of the project's learning materials aims to advance knowledge about how examining authentic secondary students' mathematical practices on technology-based algebraic tasks can support prospective secondary mathematics teachers' development of technological pedagogical content knowledge.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Meaningful use of technology tools in secondary mathematics classrooms can have a significant impact on students’ understanding of and attitudes toward mathematics. To achieve such outcomes, teachers need to develop a model of teaching and learning that goes beyond the specifics of a technology tool so that they are able to make informed decisions about the appropriate use of technology to develop mathematically proficient students. This project built from expansive prior research on teaching mathematics with technology and the success of several prior NSF-funded projects through a collaborative research effort across four institutions: Middle Tennessee State University (DUE 1820998), University of North Carolina at Charlotte (DUE 1821054), East Carolina University (DUE 1820967), and North Carolina State University (DUE 1820976). 

 

The research team brought together expertise in research, curriculum development, technological design, and mathematics teacher education to design, study, refine, and publish teacher education curriculum materials and provide support for faculty to implement the curriculum. Specifically, the project created and studied 8 video-enhanced modules for prospective secondary mathematics teachers (PSTs) to examine students’ authentic mathematical practices on technology-enhanced algebraic tasks. Each module features several video cases of secondary students’ work on technology-enhanced tasks with a focus on developing PST’s technological and pedagogical knowledge for teaching algebra and functions. Altogether, the project produced 60 picture-in-picture videos of students using various technology tools.

Intellectual Merit 

The project has shown that examining authentic secondary students’ mathematical practices on technology-based algebraic tasks supports PSTs’ development of knowledge of students’ understandings, thinking, and learning with technology in algebraic contexts, as well as their own algebraic understanding. Specifically, findings from our research has shown that PSTs that completed courses in which the project materials were used: 1) improved in their practice of noticing and anticipating student thinking on technology-enhanced tasks, 2) expressed a vision of high quality mathematics instruction with technology-enhanced mathematics tasks that aligns with research on high-quality teaching mathematics with technology, 3) grew to consider the role of the teacher as important in enacting high quality technology-enhanced mathematics tasks, and 4) designed high quality technology-enhanced mathematics tasks. 

 

The work of this project team was awarded two National Technology Leadership Initiative Fellowship awards (2018, 2021) for research papers presented at the Association of Mathematics Teacher Educators conference. In 2024, the collection of PTMT projects received the Innovators Award by the NC Council of Teachers of Mathematics for its pioneering and long lasting impact. The current project team has:

  • Published a set of design principles for development of curriculum materials that aims to develop PSTs’ advanced knowledge by engaging PSTs in approximations of practice through a lens of noticing student thinking.

  • Published a theoretical framework for noticing student thinking specifically in technology-enhanced environments. This framework draws on existing literature related to teacher noticing and instrumental genesis to highlight the importance of attending to and interpreting actions students take with technology and what they see as a result of those actions.

  • Disseminated findings in 18 peer reviewed articles, 4 peer reviewed book chapters, 17 peer reviewed conference proceedings, and 28 peer reviewed conference presentations. Topics include high quality and equitable mathematics instruction with technology-enhanced tasks, noticing student thinking in technology-enhanced environments, PSTs’ development of knowledge for teaching, and PSTs’ mathematical reasoning when examining student practices on technology-enhanced tasks.

Broader Impacts

The project supported a community of faculty at other universities through professional learning workshops and distribution of materials on our website. The project materials have had more than 10,000 page views since going live in January 2023. The vast majority of website users (90%) are located across the U.S. as well as in 24 other countries such as India, South Korea, Turkey and Australia. We disseminated the materials and research both domestically and internationally through conference presentations, invited webinars, and workshops. Additionally, 39 mathematics teacher educators participated in one-day workshops to learn about the materials and collaborate on incorporating them into courses at their home institutions. Conservatively, if we assume each of those 39 faculty members has taught 15 college students in each year since participating in the workshops, then at least 870 college students (future math teachers) have been directly impacted by the project materials (in addition to the use of materials at the 4 project institutions). Strong preparation of secondary mathematics teachers supports future generations of students prepared to enter STEM fields. By ensuring teachers are prepared to anticipate and draw upon students’ understandings in technological contexts, improving their use of technology tools in mathematics classroom, the project has also contributed to many secondary students’ preparation to pursue STEM careers.

Long-term Access to Curricula Materials

All materials from this project, as well as materials from prior related NSF-supported projects, are available on a no-registration public website. This allows many future generations of faculty to access these high-quality materials for free. http://ptmtproject.com
